arch:property.oc:show_val: This appears to be an oven, mostly because it is very soft and it is surrounded on two and one half sides by a wall. On the other hand, it did not ever give a lot of oven material such as large caches of bone. At the bottom of the oven was a crusty clay baked surface on the south side and some bricks underneath on the north side. Bounded by wall L1035.
Soft ashy fill, not a rich or organic ash but still very soft.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: appears to have been built upon the black ashy layer, of whi
square oven, oven wall found on two and one half sides. In addition, this oven and its associated wall appears to have cut into the large pavement.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 1 / Locus 1031 (Locus)
